awd_titl_txt: Underrepresented Students in Topology and Algebra Research Symposium (USTARS)
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will support participant travel for two-hundred and thirty participants to attend three Underrepresented Students in Topology and Algebra Research Symposia (USTARS) to be held April 6-8, 2018 at Reed College, in April 2019 at Iowa State University, and in April 2020 at the University of Iowa.  The goal of the symposia is to highlight research being conducted by underrepresented students in the areas of algebra and topology. Speakers will give 30-minute parallel research talks and graduate students will give at least three-quarters of these presentations. The topics of the presentations will span algebra and topology. Two distinguished graduate students and one invited faculty member will be asked to give one-hour presentations, and a poster session featuring invited undergraduates is also planned.
 
At this unique meeting, participants are exposed to a variety of current research, ideas, and results in their areas of study and beyond. Participants are also given the opportunity to meet and network with students and faculty members from underrepresented groups. USTARS promotes diversity in the mathematical sciences by encouraging women and minorities to attend and give talks, and USTARS exposes all participants to the research and activities of mathematicians from underrepresented groups, encouraging a more collaborative mathematics community. Further details and an application are available at the conference website: www.ustars.org.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This award funded participant travel and lodging for over 150 student participants to attend to USTARS 2018 at Reed College, USTARS 2019 at Iowa State University, and USTARS 2023 at the University of Washington. (USTARS 2020 and USTARS 2022 were cancelled due to the pandemic, and USTARS 2021 was hosted virtually by ICERM). 

The primary mission of the Underrepresented Students in Topology and Algebra Research Symposium (USTARS) is to showcase the excellent research conducted by underrepresented students studying topology and algebra. Dedicated to furthering the success of underrepresented students, USTARS seeks to broaden the participation in the mathematical sciences by cultivating research and mentoring networks. USTARS is open to all people interested in the topological and algebraic fields.

USTARS 2018 showcased the excellent research conducted by underrepresented graduate students to over 50 participants through 15 half-hour talks in three parallel sessions and a poster session including 11 poster presentations. 

USTARS 2019 was hosted April 26-28, 2019 at Iowa State University.  USTARS 2019 showcased the excellent research conducted by underrepresented graduate students through 9 half-hour talks in parallel sessions and a poster session including 7 poster presentations.

Information on USTARS 2021, which was hosted virtually by ICERM and did not require travel support for participants, is available at ICERM's website https://icerm.brown.edu/topical_workshops/tw-21-ustars/

USTARS 2023 was hosted March 16-18, 2023 at the University of Washington. This event was organized by a new team of organizers who were all past participants: William Frazier (University of Minnesota), Ryan Moruzzi Jr (CSU East Bay), Javier Ronquillo (BEAM), Sheri Tamagawa (Pomona College), Christopher O'Neill (San Diego State University), Anisah Nu'Man (Spelman College), and Paige Helms (University of Washington). USTARS 2023 showcased the excellent research conducted by underrepresented graduate students through 16 half-hour talks in parallel sessions and a poster session including 12 poster presentations.  These talks covered research areas including, but not limited to, AMS Subject Classfication codes: 05 Combinatorics, 11 Number Theory, 13 Commutative Algebra, 14 Algebraic Geometry, 16 Associative Algebras, 17 Nonassociative Rings and Algebra, 20 Group Theory and Generalizations, 22 Topological Groups, Lie Groups, 54 General Topology, 55 Algebraic Topology, and 57 Manifolds and Cell Complexes. 14 of the 15 talks were presented by graduate students, and all 11 posters were presented by graduate and undergraduate students.

 

All three conferences featured professional development panels where participants were invited to ask for advice on how to apply to graduate schools, find jobs, give great presentations, and become active in research opportunities.  The professional development panels consisted of groups of faculty and students of diverse backgrounds, career stages, and academic experiences. 


Last Modified: 07/30/2023
Modified by: Erik A Insko
